sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: The pred function accepts an integer, character, or an enumerated value and returns the integer minus one, the previous character, or the previous value in the enumeration. For example, pred ( 7 ) is 6.
sections.text_content: The pred function accepts an integer, character, or an enumerated value and returns the integer minus one, the previous character, or the previous value in the enumeration. For example, pred ( 7 ) is 6.
sections.mdown_content: The **pred** function accepts an integer, character, or an enumerated value and returns the integer minus one, the previous character, or the previous value in the enumeration. For example, **pred** ( 7 ) is 6.

sections.title: Example
code:
type colors : enum ( green, yellow, red )
        var a : array 1 .. 100 of colors
        var c : colors := colors . red
        for i : 1 .. 100
            a ( i ) := c
            if c = colors . green then
                c := colors . red
            else
                c := pred ( c )
            end if
        end for
sections.raw_content: This part of a Turing program fills up array a with the enumerated values red, yellow, green, red, yellow, green, etc.
sections.text_content: This part of a Turing program fills up array a with the enumerated values red, yellow, green, red, yellow, green, etc.
sections.mdown_content: This part of a Turing program fills up array *a *with the enumerated values *red*,* yellow*,* green*,* red*,* yellow*,* green*,* *etc.

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content: It is illegal to apply pred to the first value of an enumeration.
sections.text_content: It is illegal to apply pred to the first value of an enumeration.
sections.mdown_content: It is illegal to apply **pred** to the first value of an enumeration.
